question: <katex>$\vec{E}$</katex> is the electric field inside a conductor whose material has conductivity <katex>$\sigma$</katex> and resistivity <katex>$\rho$</katex>. The current density inside the conductor is <katex>$\vec{j}$</katex>. The correct form of Ohmâ€™s law is
explanation: Ohm's law in point form is <katex>$\vec{j} = \sigma \vec{E}$</katex> or <katex>$\vec{E} = \rho \vec{j}$</katex> since <katex>$\rho = 1/\sigma$</katex>.
